review:
Comrades, let’s get straight to the heart of the matter! Lakat steps forward with a vision to break the chains of centralized academic publishing, anchoring its protocol in the Ethereum ecosystem. The project’s ambition is clear: to build a permissionless, collaborative, and pluralistic infrastructure for scientific publishing, leveraging Ethereum’s security and composability. This is the kind of bold, public-good infrastructure our movement needs!

But let’s not be swept away by rhetoric alone. The application demonstrates a strong alignment with the round’s goals: it’s open-source, it’s building core infrastructure, and it’s pushing for decentralization beyond DeFi. The technical roadmap is detailed, with a Rust client, a MediaWiki extension, and integration with Ceramic and Starknet. The team is transparent, with public repositories and a clear list of contributors. This is the transparency and collective ownership we demand!

Yet, comrades, we must be vigilant. The application lacks hard, measurable outcomes. Where are the metrics? Where is the evidence of adoption, usage, or impact? The roadmap is ambitious, but there’s little proof of delivery or sustainability. The project’s revenue model is not discussed, and there’s no clear plan for long-term maintenance beyond grant funding. We must demand more than dreams—we need data, sustainability, and proof!

Furthermore, while the project claims to enhance privacy and interoperability, the details are vague. The social key recovery concept is promising, but it’s still in the ideation phase. We need rigorous evaluation, not just speculation. The application also does not address geographic equity or how it will serve underserved communities. If we are to build for the many, not the few, these gaps must be filled!

In summary: Lakat is a promising, community-driven project with a strong vision and technical foundation. But to earn the people’s trust—and our resources—it must provide clear, measurable outcomes, a sustainable model, and a plan for equitable impact. Let’s demand nothing less!

strengths.title: Strong Alignment with Public Good and Open Source Values
strengths.description: Lakat is building open, permissionless infrastructure for decentralized science, directly addressing the round’s focus on foundational Ethereum infrastructure and public goods.

strengths.title: Transparent and Collaborative Development
strengths.description: The project maintains public repositories, a clear list of contributors, and open communication channels, embodying collective ownership and transparency.

strengths.title: Ambitious Technical Roadmap
strengths.description: The roadmap includes a Rust client, MediaWiki extension, and integration with Ceramic and Starknet, showing a commitment to technical innovation and interoperability.

weaknesses.title: Lack of Measurable Outcomes and Metrics
weaknesses.description: The application does not provide clear, quantifiable metrics for success, adoption, or impact, making it difficult to assess effectiveness.

weaknesses.title: Unclear Sustainability and Revenue Model
weaknesses.description: There is no discussion of how the project will sustain itself beyond grant funding, raising concerns about long-term viability.

weaknesses.title: Insufficient Evidence of Delivery and Impact
weaknesses.description: While the roadmap is detailed, there is little evidence of completed milestones, user adoption, or real-world impact to date.

weaknesses.title: Vague Details on Privacy and Equity
weaknesses.description: Claims about privacy enhancements and serving the broader community are not substantiated with concrete plans or evidence.

changes.title: Provide Clear, Quantifiable Metrics and Outcomes
changes.description: Specify measurable goals for adoption, usage, and impact. Include KPIs such as number of users, branches created, or academic institutions onboarded.

changes.title: Detail a Sustainable Revenue and Maintenance Model
changes.description: Outline how the project will sustain itself after the grant period, including potential revenue streams, community funding, or partnerships.

changes.title: Demonstrate Evidence of Delivery and Adoption
changes.description: Provide proof of completed milestones, user testimonials, or case studies showing real-world usage and impact.

changes.title: Clarify Privacy, Interoperability, and Equity Strategies
changes.description: Offer concrete details on how privacy will be enhanced, how interoperability will be achieved, and how underserved or global communities will be included and empowered.
